Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA)

Strengthening Knowledge-Driven Development in 
South Asia 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA), which is anchored on the core components of Strategy 
2020,1 responds to the inherent demands of developing member countries (DMCs) for greater 
application of knowledge in Asian Development Bank (ADB) operations and for enhancement of 
their  own  knowledge  of  relevant  ADB  guidelines,  rules,  and  regulations.  Continuous 
engagement with DMC governments in the region has shown the need for robust knowledge 
management in development operations. The TA thus stems from the need for ADB to better 
engage  with  DMCs  in  generating  and  sharing  knowledge  that  will  help  enhance  the 
effectiveness of development operations. 
 
2.  The governments of the South Asian DMCs concur with the impact, outcome, outputs, 
implementation  arrangements,  costs,  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference.  The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The key issue for knowledge-driven development emanates from the core precept of use 
of  knowledge  solutions3 to  better  design  and  implement  policy  reforms  and  development 
programs and projects. In this context, DMCs need knowledge from ADB that is evidence-based 
and that guides them on what works and what does not. They need critical analyses of risks that 
they face, and how others may or may not have adequately addressed them.  
 
4.  DMC officials in core ministries (such as finance, treasury, planning) and in sector line 
ministers  (such  as  health,  education,  local  development)  are  not  always  aware  of—and 
engaged in—the intellectual debate on development thinking, shifts in development paradigms, 
planning methodologies, cross-jurisdictional good practice in public management, and current 
economic trends and political economy considerations. While these issues have often been an 
afterthought, jurisdictions that have had significant learning experiences in development have 
generally made investments in incorporating knowledge in development efforts (for instance, 
New Zealand and Singapore). 
 
5.  What is important is that ADB involvement in DMC development efforts also mandates 
that it too enhance knowledge solutions in this work.4 The value-addition that ADB provides to 
DMCs is not just in making financial resources available but also in offering advice on technical 
issues and policy reforms (the so-called “finance ++” concept). This implies that ADB staff must 
                                                 
 
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. Available: www.adb.org/strategy2020/ 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 August 2011. 
3  For purposes of this TA, the term is taken to mean inputs to solving development problems that make use of 
information from guides, tools, methods, approaches, and practical experience. At the core of this term is the 
concept of use of information and knowledge that is practical. 
4 This is particularly true for SARD whose DMCs are diverse in size and characteristics, as implied by (i) their 
borrowing status (India–ordinary capital resources (OCR) only; Bangladesh and Sri Lanka–blend OCR and Asian 
Development Fund (ADF); Nepal–ADF loans and grants, and Bhutan and the Maldives–ADF loans); (ii) area and 
population  (from  India  with  almost  1.2  billion  people  to  the  Maldives  with  just  314,000);  (iii)  degree  of 
implementation capacity in bureaucracy (from rather high in Bhutan to very low in Nepal); and (iv) variance in 
degree of portfolio performance. Hence, a one-size-fits-all approach is not likely to succeed here, and country-
specific knowledge, and application of such knowledge, is paramount in operations work in DMCs of the South 
Asia Department.

2  
be  knowledgeable  on issues  that impact  DMC  development  efforts.  ADB’s  recent  drive  to 
enhance staff skills so that development of DMCs is fostered is a good reflection of this. 
 
6.  Internal reviews of project success and analysis of why some development efforts have 
not had positive results show two key relevant factors: (i) lack of capacity of DMC officials and 
project staff; and (ii) poor quality at entry, including lack of proper initial assessment of the 
situation on the ground and prior lessons, inadequate technical analysis, and lack of more 
detailed sector analysis work in program or project design. Both have deep implications for 
knowledge management. With proper dissemination of knowledge (e.g., of ADB procedures and 
requirements), DMC officials and project staff would be more skilled and knowledgeable to 
better manage programs and projects. With better and more complete knowledge, quality at 
entry  in  program  and  project  development  would  be  that  much  more  rigorous  (e.g.,  due 
diligence would be more realistic and complete). With better programs, based on accurate 
information and analysis (including of risks), coupled with more capable staff, the probability of 
successful program outcomes that contribute to poverty reduction will increase—the vision of 
ADB for the region. 
 
7.  Thus,  knowledge  management  work  is  critical,  and  the  application  of  knowledge 
solutions to the development and policy planning work of DMCs will ensure that they are able to 
attain their development objectives effectively.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be evident in more relevant and sustainable development 
efforts in the DMCs of South Asia.5 The outcome is better informed development policies and 
strategies in these DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will capitalize on DMC demand for specific knowledge products and services, 
support operations-based knowledge creation in the DMCs of South Asia, and utilize research 
work carried out in the design of programs and projects. The TA also involves the wide sharing 
of knowledge among the DMCs and ADB staff. Outputs expected from the TA and relevant 
activities, include the following: 
 
(i)  Knowledge  products.  These  will  provide  in-depth,  relevant,  and  timely 
assessments, policy proposals, and recommendations so that the DMCs can 
address immediate and long-term development issues. In particular, this includes 
working papers; research reports on subjects of topical interest; proceedings of 
conferences,  symposiums,  forums,  and  workshops;  program  and  policy 
evaluation compendiums; and others, including risk assessments, books, policy 
toolkits, blogs, seminar presentations, research alerts, and newsletters. 
 
                                                 
 
5  The concepts of “relevance” and “sustainable” are drawn from the analytical framework used by, among others, the 
Independent Evaluation Department. Cases where ADB interventions are assessed as relevant and sustainable 
always include strong evidence of rigorous due diligence and great awareness of the development situation. Both 
of these are intrinsically tied to the application of knowledge management in ADB  work. Appendix 1 and  
Appendix 4 detail the project design and problem analysis work.

3
(ii)  Knowledge events. Within ADB and the DMCs of South Asia, these events will 
help  generate,  share,  and  apply  knowledge.  They  include  (a)  economists’ 
conference with participation of DMC officials; (b) eminent speakers’ forum on 
issues faced by DMCs in South Asia, including on public policy and political 
economy; (c) policy workshops with DMC officials; and (d) others, such as site 
visits with, and study visits for, relevant DMC officials. 
 
(iii)  Active  regional  knowledge  partnerships  and  networks.  These  are  to 
generate and disseminate knowledge to the DMCs and help share knowledge 
with them. While partnerships in South Asia have been developed6 (and these 
will be sustained), more value-addition needs to be generated to expand these to 
a premier institute (or institutes) in Asia and the Pacific. This partnership can help 
elevate  discussions  and  debate  on  economic  and  financial  trends  and 
development paradigms as well as link up with institutions across regions to 
begin a wider partnership on knowledge sharing. 
 
(iv)  Project implementation on time and within budget. This is related to project 
management and is generated for every project. 
 
10.  The TA has no risks related to social and environmental concerns, public financial 
management, procurement, or corruption. Risks related to the project are detailed in the design 
and  monitoring  framework  (Appendix  1).  The  TA  makes  certain  assumptions  about  the 
operating environment for knowledge management in the DMCs. Four that are relevant to the 
TA work at hand include (i) no extraneous adverse conditions impact development efforts (this 
is  an  important  assumption  since  well-designed  development  programs  and  projects  are 
expected to yield positive impacts); (ii) rigorous due diligence exercises are not prohibitive by 
way of cost and time; (iii) DMC demand for knowledge products and events from ADB continues; 
and (iv) project staff members in the DMCs have opportunities to participate in knowledge 
events so that they can be more aware of, and knowledgeable about, ADB procedures. 
 
11.  The TA has four risks: (i) political considerations may undermine effectiveness of some 
development efforts, and thus take away from the rigor of the program and project; (ii) DMC 
governments may refuse to internalize risk assessment work, which is not an insignificant issue 
since risk assessments, by their very nature, highlight some difficult choices to be made by 
governments; (iii) reports and assessments available for DMC review may not be deemed 
relevant when completed, i.e., knowledge management work could tend to be merely an ivory 
tower exercise; and (iv) regional knowledge networks may have different research interests or 
capacity mismatches during the TA period, a risk that would emerge if sufficient due diligence is 
not carried out prior to contracting the relevant knowledge partner(s). 
 
12.  The primary risk mitigation measure will be continuous engagement with governments 
(including through resident missions as needed) to address the political considerations risk and 
that of lack of internalization of risk assessment work. Other risk mitigation measures will 
include: (i) engaging with DMCs early on in the programming cycle (such as during the country 
partnership  and  strategy  exercise);  (ii)  constantly  monitoring  the  quality  of  the  knowledge 
products  and  events;  and  (iii)  ensuring  that  the  DMCs  are  involved  in  their  design  and 
implementation, which will minimize the risk of knowledge work being considered an ivory tower 
                                                 
 
6  For example, the South Asia Center for Policy Studies and South Asia Network of Economic Research Institutes.

4  
exercise. Engagement could be in the form of involvement in missions related to portfolio review, 
country programming review, and country partnership and strategy design exercises.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.5 million equivalent. The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF); $500,000 from TASF-IV 
and $1,000,000 from TASF-others (Appendix 2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  Executing and implementing agencies. ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. 
The  South  Asia  Regional  Cooperation  and  Operations  Coordination  Division  (SARC),  the 
implementing agency, will coordinate closely with the DMCs of South Asia participating resident 
missions and sector divisions, and other departments in ADB (such as the Economic Research 
Department, Office of Regional Economic Integration, Strategy and Policy Department, and 
Regional and Sustainable Development Department). 
 
15.  Project steering committee. A project steering committee (PSC) will be established to 
be chaired by the SARC director and comprising members who are knowledge focal points in 
the sector divisions and resident missions (these focal points have already been designated). 
The committee will meet every 4 months, at which time representatives from the non-SARD 
departments may be invited to join, as deemed necessary. Day-to-day TA operations will be 
under  the  guidance  of  SARC’s  principal  knowledge  management  specialist  with  active 
involvement of a knowledge management coordinator (individual national consultant). 
 
16.  Project duration. The project will run from December 2011 to December 2014. 
 
17.  Consultancy inputs. ADB will engage the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Details on the consultants and 
their terms of reference are available in Table 1 and Appendix 3. No procurement of any goods 
is envisaged. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
18.  Complementary inputs. Other ADB inputs to the TA include (i) research publications, 
reports, software, and database(s) necessary to undertake research activities; (ii) office space 
and facilities, as may be required to carry out the research; (iii) conference and forum venues 
for all knowledge activities organized at headquarters and in the resident missions; and (iv) peer 
review provisions for research work to be carried out as part of the TA. Complementary inputs 
from  DMC  governments  will  include  venues,  as  needed,  for  seminars  and  symposiums 
organized by DMC governments; counterpart staff to be involved in knowledge management 
work; and local transport for DMC officials involved in TA-related research and analyses. 
 
19.  Project  monitoring,  peer  review,  and  reporting. The PSC will monitor and guide 
project  implementation  progress.  The  quarterly  PSC  meeting  will  monitor  project  progress 
based  on  the  agreed  pipeline  of  outputs  identified  during  consultations  with  government 
agencies, research organizations, and development institutions. Peer review within ADB and by 
other research and academic institutions will be used as a tool to evaluate the quality and depth 
of  analysis  of  working  papers,  policy  briefs,  and  other  studies.  A  progress  report  will  be 
prepared for discussion at each PSC meeting (i.e., every 4 months). A TA completion report will 
evaluate TA achievements against the targeted outputs.

20.  SARC will closely monitor deadlines set for all publications work, including timely printing 
and delivery. For the knowledge products, the Economic Research Department, Regional and 
Sustainable Development Department, and Office of Regional Economic Integration, among 
others within ADB, will play a key role in monitoring quality and providing peer review, as 
needed, to enhance quality. 
 
21.  Good practices and lessons from the TA will be disseminated through (i) several policy 
forums,  workshops,  and  seminars  to  share  the  results  of  relevant  knowledge  generation 
activities; (ii) policy briefs and other documents provided to DMC governments and others to 
consider for incorporation when formulating development policies; (iii) websites of ADB and 
DMC governments; and (iv) publication in relevant practitioner and academic-based knowledge 
sources, such as peer-reviewed journals. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis 
for Strengthening Knowledge-Driven Development in South Asia, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
AND KNOWLEDGE PARTNERS 
 
1.  A total of 21 person-months of international and 92 person-months of national consulting 
services will be required to ensure that the technical assistance (TA) is effectively managed and 
the outcome achieved. Five types of individual consulting services will be required, and will be 
bolstered by partnership(s) with regional institution(s) that will support knowledge management 
work of the South Asia Department (SARD). 
 
A.  Knowledge Management Coordinator (36 person-months, national, individual)  
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will engage a knowledge management coordinator 
for the full period of TA implementation (i.e., 36 person-months). The consultant will be a 
generalist  with  good  project  administration  skills;  have  prior  exposure  to  knowledge 
management work (ADB exposure preferred) and experience in working with economic datasets, 
country information, and writing reports, newsletters, and briefs; and have broad knowledge of 
knowledge management principles. A postgraduate degree in economics and other relevant 
social sciences is required. 
 
3.  The  coordinator  will  be  responsible  for  the  following  outputs:  project  management; 
website  management;  support  to  all  conferences,  meetings,  and  seminars;  production  of 
conference, seminar, and workshop proceedings; and reporting for the project. In particular, the 
consultant will 
 
(i)  serve as overall coordinator and knowledge manager for the TA project; 
(ii)  examine best practices in knowledge sharing and management, and recommend 
appropriate approaches for the TA; 
(iii)  lead and design knowledge events and preparation of materials and activities on 
key issues in the region, in close collaboration with SARC staff; 
(iv)  prepare a plan for the regional dissemination and management of knowledge 
products, primarily using web-based forums and venues; 
(v)  support knowledge solutions by liaising with resident mission(s) and other SARD 
staff  regarding  proposed  sector  and  thematic  studies  for  the  annual  SARD 
economists’  conference  and  South  Asia  working  papers  (SAWPs),  including 
organizing workshops and meetings;  
(vi)  handle ad hoc requests of network research institutions and DMC agencies for 
ADB research information; 
(vii)  facilitate  the  appropriate  protocol  required  for  events  and  coordinate  all 
necessary required logistical arrangements for the conduct of the TA and other 
events  (conferences,  meetings,  workshops,  seminars),  including  venue  and 
travel  arrangements,  disbursements  of  per  diem  to  resource  persons  and 
international consultants, and liquidation of expenses;  
(viii)  draft quarterly progress reports for submission to the project steering committee;  
(ix)  edit and check the quality of the reports and consistency with the ADB Handbook 
of Style and Usage; 
(x)  compile all final prints and electronic versions of SAWPs and other studies;  
(xi)  generate and manage relevant databases for SARD research and operations; 
(xii)  assist in engaging with resident missions and SARD sector divisions to identify 
relevant knowledge products and how to generate and disseminate them; and  
(xiii)  undertake other tasks as needed.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
 
B.  Economic Editor (3 person-months, international, individual)  
 
4.  The editor will have a master’s degree or higher in economics (in any subfield), and prior 
experience in preparing and reviewing economic reports, preferably in a developing country 
context. Both public and private sector professional experience will be considered relevant. 
 
5.  The editor will be responsible for the outputs related to the SAWPs and other relevant 
research reports. Under the supervision of SARC staff, and in consultation with other staff in 
SARD involved in preparing and writing SAWPs, the editor will 
 
(i)  review the analytical framework of the working paper(s) and the research report(s) 
for consistency of logic and rigor; 
(ii)  edit papers and reports for consistency with economic theory, as appropriate, as 
well as empirical evidence; 
(iii)  edit papers and reports for internal consistency in accordance with the ADB 
Handbook of Style and Usage; 
(iv)  ensure that language style is consistent throughout the publication; 
(v)  check references to tables, figures, appendixes, bibliographies, and parts of the 
text; 
(vi)  edit notes to make sure that text references are correct; and 
(vii)  be responsible for typesetting and proofreading the text, tables, and charts in the 
paper(s) and report(s), and take the work from preliminary draft to final copy, 
including  producing  the  high-resolution  PDF  file  to  be  submitted  to  the 
Department of External Relations. 
 
C.  Guest  Speakers  (2  person-months  international,  and  5  person-months  national; 
individual)  
 
6.  Given that the TA focuses on such events as flagship forums, eminent speakers’ forums, 
and conferences, guest speakers will be contracted for individual events, which will enhance the 
availability of new ideas on development trends and paradigms and emergent strategic thinking 
on development. These speakers will be noted academicians, practitioners, and thought leaders 
in  their  own  right,  and  have  demonstrated  credibility  in  their  sphere  of  work  and  area  of 
expertise.  While  the  services  of  some  of  these  guest  speakers  will  be  contracted  for  the 
proposed eminent speakers’ forum, others will be involved in other conferences and forums that 
ADB or DMCs will organize. 
 
7.  The guest speakers will be responsible for the following outputs: (i) presentations on 
topics  of  interest  to  DMCs  and  ADB,  and  (ii)  knowledge  product(s)  resulting  from  their 
participation in the knowledge events. In particular, the guest speakers will 
 
(i)  prepare speaking notes on topics for which they are being requested to present; 
(ii)  prepare presentations that will be circulated prior to the knowledge events; 
(iii)  present their ideas and engage in discussion with the event audience; 
(iv)  be available to engage in separate discussions with interested staff members 
and DMC officials as part of their involvement in the knowledge event; 
(v)  prepare a report on the topic for wider dissemination; and 
(vi)  serve as a discussant at conferences and symposiums, as required.

Appendix 3  11 
 
 
D.  Resource  Persons  (2  person-months  international,  and  5  person-months  national; 
individual)  
 
8.  The nature of the knowledge management work envisaged for the TA requires the inputs 
of several resource persons. They will have had exposure to the specific theme(s) on which the 
knowledge events and knowledge products will be designed; all will have at least postgraduate 
academic qualifications and at least 10 years of experience in their areas of expertise. They will 
be responsible for the following outputs: well-designed and -run knowledge events, and well-
prepared knowledge products emanating from these events and other research work. They will 
 
(i)  help conceptualize major knowledge events; 
(ii)  contribute to their design and implementation, as needed; 
(iii)  serve as peer reviewer of materials to be presented at the event(s) and later to 
be published; 
(iv)  facilitate training and similar types workshops, as needed; and 
(v)  be available to provide advice on how to operationalize the learning from the 
knowledge events. 
 
E.  Research Specialists (10 person-months international, and 36 person-months national; 
individual)  
 
9.  ADB  will  hire  various  research  specialists  to  carry  out  research  requests  from 
government  agencies  and  other  relevant  network  research  institutions.  The  international 
consultants will have undertaken similar work with a minimum of 10 years work experience in 
developing  countries  and  institutions  similar  to  ADB;  and  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in 
economics,  political  science,  public  administration,  public  policy,  or  another  relevant  social 
science field.  
 
10.  National consultants will be engaged for the sector and thematic studies under the TA, 
and be asked to work with ADB staff and other national consultants, as appropriate. The 
consultants should have a master’s degree in economics or other relevant social science field, 
plus at least 5 years of professional experience with extensive working experience in South Asia 
in one or more of the following fields: regional economic integration, trade, regional cooperation, 
energy, transport, environment, and other priority sectors.  
 
11.  Under  the  direct  supervision  of  relevant  SARD  staff,  the  consultants  will  help  with 
SARD’s research work for its SAWPs and other relevant research agenda. They are expected 
to perform the selected tasks: 
 
(i)  undertake research on issues related to economic development, growth, trade, 
regional cooperation, energy, transport, environment, and other priority sectors; 
(ii)  conduct  data  gathering  and  quantitative  analyses,  and  assist  in  preparing 
working paper(s) and other research report(s); 
(iii)  revise  and  finalize  working  paper(s)  and  report(s)  based  on  reviews  and 
comments from the review panel and the editor; 
(iv)  serve as peer reviewer for all research work in SARD and under the TA;  
(v)  prepare  topical  research  paper(s)  on  key  public  policy  issue(s)  as  may  be 
requested by government agencies and relevant development institutions; and 
(vi)  carryout ad hoc research and other assignments as necessary.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
12.  Research  specialists  will  be  responsible for  all  outputs  related  to  SARD’s  research 
agenda and portfolio of knowledge work. 
 
F.  Strategic  Planners  (4 person-months international, and 10 person-months national; 
individual) 
 
13.  ADB will recruit strategic planners to assist national planning agencies (particularly in 
Bhutan and Nepal, given the need to support the strategic planning exercise in those countries). 
The international consultants will have undertaken similar work with a minimum of 10 years of 
work experience in developing countries, and preferably in South Asia. National consultants will 
have had an equal number of years of professional experience, with particular focus on working 
with  central  planning  agencies  in  plan  formulation.  All  the  consultants  should  have  a 
postgraduate degree in economics, political science, public administration, public policy, or 
another relevant social science field.  
 
14.  Under the direct supervision of the relevant resident mission in the case of Nepal, and 
SARC in the case of Bhutan, the consultants will work with the central planning agencies to  
 
(i)  assess the rigor of the planning methodologies for the strategic plans; 
(ii)  advise  the  planning  agencies  on  good  practice  in  strategic  planning  in 
comparable jurisdictions; 
(iii)  assist in planning for relevant study visits of government officials, particularly to 
ensure that lessons are incorporated in the planning exercise; 
(iv)  assist in data gathering, analysis, and other relevant tasks in the preparation of 
national plans; 
(v)  engage with other relevant government departments and development partners 
in the design of the national plans; 
(vi)  serve as peer reviewer, as needed, for all planning documentation prepared by 
the agency; and 
(vii)  carry out ad hoc activities as requested by the planning agency. 
 
15.  The strategic planning consultants will be responsible for preparing knowledge products 
related to the project’s relevant component on knowledge product generation. 
 
G.  Regional Knowledge Creation and Network Partner(s) (international firms, 36 person-
months) 
 
16.  A substantial component of the TA has to do with the formalization of one or more 
knowledge  network  partnerships  in  the  region  with  premier  think  tank(s),  research 
organization(s), or academic institution(s). The purpose of this partnership is to be engaged with 
a credible institution that cannot only elevate the learning of ADB and the DMCs in the region 
but also enable policymakers from one region to interact meaningfully with those from another 
(such as between South Asia and East Asia). All such institutions that will be partners with ADB 
will have a credible, demonstrated, and relevant research and practical agenda in policy making, 
economic analysis, and development work. They will ideally have an academic program as well 
and  deep  connections  with  a  well-known  university  and/or  government  with  international 
recognition as a path-breaker in public policy and economic reforms. The institutions will also 
have research and academic staff members that specialize in, or that have exposure to, South 
Asia.

Appendix 3  13 
 
17.  The regional knowledge network partner(s) will (i) coordinate across the two networks 
(South Asia Center for Policy Studies and South Asia Network of Economic Research Institutes) 
in South Asia and work with subregional groups, such as South Asia Association for Regional 
Cooperation  and  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic  Cooperation,  to  help  analyze  recent 
development  and  economic  trends,  and  provide  research  support  to  existing  knowledge 
networks in the SARD DMCs; (ii) enable engagement of South Asian policy leaders with those 
of  other  regions;  (iii)  serve  as  knowledge  hub  in  bringing  together  research  and  strategic 
thinking in the development agenda of DMCs in South Asia and elsewhere (e.g., East Asia); (iv) 
provide thought leadership on development issues of the day as well as long-term development 
issues  that  are  likely  to  emerge;  and  (v)  hold  necessary  symposiums,  forums,  seminars, 
workshops, and training sessions, to enhance the awareness and skills of officials in the SARD 
DMCs, and publish the resulting knowledge products. 
 
18.  The regional knowledge network partner(s) will be responsible for all the TA outputs that 
have to do with interactions with, and knowledge sharing across, regions as well as knowledge 
generation and dissemination on relevant development themes in South Asia itself.
